thought: The WHOIS information shows that the domain 'windows.net' is legitimately registered to Microsoft Corporation. However, the subdomain 'pushanc63e.z13.web.core.windows.net' could be a misuse of the legitimate Windows Azure cloud services. The 404 error suggests that either the page has been taken down or never existed, which is common for temporary scam websites. To further investigate the possibility of a scam, I should check for any public reports or complaints about this URL.
observation: [{'url': 'https://malwaretips.com/blogs/remove-windows-net/', 'content': 'STEP 1: Uninstall malicious programs from Windows. STEP 2: Reset browsers back to default settings. STEP 3: Use Malwarebytes Anti-Malware to remove malware and unwanted programs. STEP 4: Use HitmanPro to scan your computer for badware. STEP 5: Use AdwCleaner to remove adware and malicious browser policies.'}, {'url': 'https://malwaretips.com/blogs/remove-the-error-code-2v7hgtvb-pop-up-scam/', 'content': 'Press the Windows key + I on your keyboard to open the Settings app. First, open Windows Settings by pressing Windows+I on your keyboard. You can also right-click your Start button and select "Settings" from the list. In the Settings app, click on "Apps" and then "Apps & features".'}, {'url': 'https://securedstatus.com/remove-web-core-windows-net-phishing/', 'content': 'Remove Web.core.windows.net from Google Chrome. 1. Open the Google Chrome application, then proceed by going to the upper-right corner of the browser window and clicking the three-dot menu button. Once the drop-down opens, select Settings. 2.'}, {'url': 'https://answers.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/forum/all/have-a-scam-come-up-saying-my-computer-is-locked/0c174617-f500-4404-b14b-55c2bfeb2355', 'content': 'Or Windows key + X and then Task Manager etc. Also see: Open Task Manager in Windows 10 | Tutorials. And/or cutting the internet and/or shutting down your computer would stop all scam actions as well. A good ad blocker should prevent pop ups/fake warnings/alerts/ads etc. Tracking blockers help too.'}, {'url': 'https://community.spiceworks.com/t/how-to-block-web-core-windows-net-phish-emails-new-twist/725994', 'content': 'A common phishing technique was to use Azure BLOB storage to host content. The URL\'s contained " web.core.windows.net ", which gave them an appearance of legitimacy. We were able to block these successfully by creating a transport rule that blocked messages with " web.core.windows.net " in the body of the message.'}]

The subdomain pattern indicates a misuse of legitimate Azure cloud services and although there are no direct reports of this URL being a scam similar patterns have been used for scams in the past.
